questions.text: What is the recommended treatment protocol for plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females in the 1st trimester with complaints of headache and fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chloroquine

 

Explanation:

 

For plasmodium vivax infection in pregnant females, especially in the first trimester, the recommended treatment is chloroquine.

 

For vivax and ovale malaria, the treatment of choice is chloroquine along with primaquine. However, in pregnancy primaquine is contraindicated.

 

Since the specifically asks about the treatment protocol for a pregnant female in the first trimester with vivax malaria, the appropriate treatment would be chloroquine alone, without primaquine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ART combined therapy - This option is incorrect because artemisinin-based combination therapy (ART) is the treatment of choice for falciparum and malariae malaria, not vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Quinine - This option is incorrect because quinine is not the recommended treatment for vivax malaria in pregnancy.

 

Option D. Chloroquine + Primaquine - This option is incorrect because primaquine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment Protocol

questions.text: Identify the classification used and grade of the shown injury in a child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gartland’s classification Type III

 

The X-ray provided shows a Supracondylar fracture of the humerus, which is classified using the Gartland classification system. The Gartland classification is specifically for supracondylar fractures, particularly in children.

 

  • Gartland Type III refers to a completely displaced fracture, with no cortical contact between the fragments. There may be either medial or lateral displacement, as seen in this case.
  • The Salter-Harris classification is used for epiphyseal plate injuries, not for supracondylar fractures. Therefore, it is not applicable in this scenario.

 

To summarize:

 

  • Gartland Type I: Undisplaced fracture.
  • Gartland Type II: Displaced fracture with the posterior cortex intact.
  • Gartland Type III: Displaced fracture with no cortical contact (either medial or lateral displacement).
  • Gartland Type IV: An intraoperative diagnosis where the periosteum is damaged both anteriorly and posteriorly, requiring more complex reduction techniques.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Salter-Harris classification Type III: Incorrect because the injury in question is not an epiphyseal fracture. Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate fractures, not supracondylar fractures.

 

Option C. Gartland’s classification Type IV: Incorrect because Gartland Type IV is an intraoperative diagnosis, which is not apparent in the provided X-ray.

 

Option D. Salter-Harris classification Type IV: Again, incorrect because this classification system pertains to epiphyseal injuries, and the X-ray shows a supracondylar fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gartland classification is specifically used for supracondylar humerus fractures in children, while the Salter-Harris classification is used for growth plate (epiphyseal) fractures.

 

Gartland classification Supracondylar humerus

 

  • Type 1: Undisplaced
  • Type 2: Displaced with posterior hinge intact
  • Type 3a: Displaced fracture with lateral hinge broken (PM)
  • Type 3b: Displaced fracture with medial hinge broken (PL)
  • Type 4: Completely displaced with both anterior and posterior periosteum avulsed (Intra-operative finding)

 

 

Salter-Harris classification of epiphyseal injuries

 

  • Type I: Fracture line is entirely with in Physis causing epiphyseal slip
  • Type II: Fracture line extends from physis into the Metaphysis (Thurston-Holland’s fragment sign)
  • Type III: Fracture line extends from physis into the Epiphysis causing epiphyseal split
  • Type IV: Fracture line extends across the Epiphysis,  (articular surface), Physis, and metaphysis
  • Type V: Crush injury of physis with initially normal X-rays

questions.text: A person was stabbed in the thigh by a knife, with a wound measuring 1×3×5 cm. What kind of wound is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Penetration

 

Explanation:

 

A wound is classified based on depth, entry and exit points, and the type of weapon used.

 

In this stab wound:

 

  • Depth (5 cm) > length (3 cm) > width (1 cm)
  • Penetrates deep into tissue
  • No exit wound mentioned 
  • Penetrating: Extends deep into cavity/tissue without exit
  • Perforating: Has both entry and exit wounds
  • Puncture: Only involves superficial tissues 

 

Types of stab wounds based on depth:

 

This case shows penetrating wound as it's deep (5 cm) but doesn't exit the body

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Perforating Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Involves both entry and exit wounds.
  • Example: A stab wound passing through the body and weapon coming out from other side.
  • Here, no exit wound is mentioned, ruling out this option.

 

Option C. Incision: Incorrect

 

  • Length is greater than depth (e.g., surgical cuts, knife slashes).
  • Here, depth (5 cm) is greater than length (1 cm), ruling out an incision.

 

Option D. Puncture Wound: Incorrect

 

  • Shallow depth, usually involving only the superficial layers.
  • Seen in  nail, or small pointed object injuries.
  • Here, the depth is significantly deep (5 cm), making it penetrating, not puncture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A penetrating wound is defined as a deep wound where depth > length, caused by sharp-pointed objects (e.g., knife, dagger, spear). A perforating wound would require both an entry and exit wound, which is not present here​

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Alcohol and its metabolites, acetaldehyde, have a toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy causes include:

 

Acquisition of causes

 

  • The most frequent causes of myocarditis worldwide are infectious (particularly coxsackievirus B) and non-infectious myocarditis.
  • In India, alcohol is the most frequent culprit.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PCM) and pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) (PPCM)
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy brought on by stress

 

Meth-related:

 

  • Doxycycline (anthracycline)
  • Cyclophosphamide and trastuzumab

 

A lack of nutrition:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency; Keshan disease (selenium); Beriberi (thiamine);
  • Endocrine: acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, hypo- and hyperthyroidism
  • Additional
  • Toxicity of cobalt, Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)

 

Genetic factors (50%):

 

Haemochromatosis; Duchenne muscular dystrophy; Becker's muscular dystrophy; cardiac myocyte titin gene mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericarditis: While alcohol can have widespread effects on the body, it is not directly associated with the development of pericarditis.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: This condition involves the thickening of the heart muscle, primarily due to genetic causes, and is not directly linked to alcohol use.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Generally caused by infections (particularly viral), autoimmune disorders, or toxic exposures, but not specifically by alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

questions.text: During an endoscopy, a man is found to have the squamo-columnar junction located proximally than normal. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this finding? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sliding hernia 

 

During an endoscopy, finding the squamo-columnar junction (also known as the Z-line) located proximally to its normal position near the gastroesophageal junction suggests a condition in which the stomach has moved upwards. 

 

Also known as a sliding hiatal hernia, this condition occurs when part of the stomach slides up through the hiatal opening in the diaphragm into the chest cavity, leading to the upward displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Achalasia cardia: This is a motility disorder of the esophagus where the lower esophageal sphincter fails to relax properly. It doesn't typically result in an upward displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Option C. Rolling hernia: A rolling or paraesophageal hernia occurs when part of the stomach herniates through the diaphragm next to the esophagus but the gastroesophageal junction stays in its normal position, so it would not typically result in the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Option D. Paraesophageal hernia: This is similar to a rolling hernia where the gastroesophageal junction remains in place, but part of the stomach rolls up through the diaphragm. It does not cause proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sliding hernia is the condition most likely responsible for the proximal displacement of the squamo-columnar junction observed during endoscopy, indicating the upward movement of the stomach through the hiatal opening.

choices.text: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption
The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock
The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion
The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow responses to trauma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response

 

Explanation

 

The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma:

 

A short ebb phase characterized by hypometabolism occurs immediately after the injury and is characterized by a decrease in metabolic rate, oxygen consumption, body temperature, and enzymatic activity. The ebb phase is followed by a longer hypermetabolic flow phase marked by an increased catabolism, with a high oxygen consumption and an elevated resting energy expenditure rate.

 

The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption: Correct, this describes the initial hypometabolic state following trauma.

 

Option B. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock: Correct, marking the transition to a hypermetabolic state.

 

Option C. The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion: Correct, as it focuses on conserving energy immediately after trauma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The statement that the "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic acute-phase response is false. These processes are characteristics of the "flow" phase, which occurs after the initial ebb phase and involves increased metabolic activity and systemic responses aimed at recovery and defense.

questions.text: According to triage, which of the following colors indicates the highest priority?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red

 

Explanation:

 

In the triage system, the red color indicates the highest priority. The triage categories and their corresponding colors are as follows:

 

Red: Category 1, highest priority. Patients requiring immediate resuscitation or life-saving surgery within 0 to 6 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow: Category 2, high priority. Possible resuscitation or possible surgery within 6 to 24 hours.

 

Option C. Green: Category 3, low priority. Ambulatory patients with non-life-threatening injuries.

 

Option D. Black: Least priority, includes dead and moribund patients.

 

The red category, which is assigned to patients requiring immediate life-saving intervention, is the highest priority in the triage system.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70 mEg/L

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder that affects multiple systems, primarily the respiratory and digestive systems, due to a defect in the CFTR gene.

 

This is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, CF patients are more likely to experience hypokalemia due to the loss of electrolytes through sweat and the effects of contraction alkalosis.

 

Other Options:

 

The diagnosis and features of cystic fibrosis include:

 

Option A. Sweat chloride test chloride concentration of 70 mEq/L: The sweat chloride test is the gold standard for diagnosing CF. A chloride concentration greater than 60 mEq/L is indicative of CF.

 

Option B. Increased immunoreactive trypsinogen level: Newborn screening for CF often includes measuring immunoreactive trypsinogen levels, which are elevated in CF patients.

 

Option D. Contraction alkalosis: CF patients can present with contraction alkalosis due to loss of water and sodium, and renal waste of potassium and hydrogen ions. This is similar to the effects seen in patients taking loop diuretics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperkalemia is not typically seen in cystic fibrosis. Instead, patients with CF may present with hypokalemia and contraction alkalosis due to electrolyte losses.

choices.text: It proceeds from effect to cause
Recall bias is a major problem

questions.text: Which of the following statements about "Case-Control Study" is incorrect? [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) It is a prospective study

 

  • Case-control studies are retrospective studies, not prospective. They look backward from the outcome (disease) to potential exposures or risk factors. 
  • In these studies, investigators select persons with the disease (cases) and without the disease (controls) and then compare their past exposures to determine associations.

 

Other Options:

 

In case-control studies, both the exposure and outcome have already occurred before the start of the study. "Case control studies, often called 'retrospective studies' are a common first approach to test causal hypothesis." Furthermore, they are characterized by working backwards from "effect to cause."

 

Option B. It proceeds from effect to cause: Correct Case-control studies begin with disease status (effect) and work backward to identify potential causes or risk factors. This backward direction from outcome to potential cause is a defining characteristic that distinguishes them from cohort studies.

 

Option C. Recall bias is a major problem: Correct Recall bias is a significant limitation of case-control studies. Since these studies rely on participants' memory of past exposures, cases (those with disease) may recall exposures differently than controls. This systematic difference in recall can distort the true relationship between exposure and disease.

 

Option D. Cost-effective: Correct Case-control studies are indeed cost-effective compared to other study designs, particularly cohort studies. They require fewer subjects and can be completed more quickly, making them a practical choice for initial investigations, especially for rare diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case-control studies are retrospective investigations that work backward from disease status to potential exposures, making them useful for rare diseases but subject to recall bias.

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the skin is false ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dermis is derived from ectoderm

 

Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

 

  • The epidermis is derived from the ectoderm, which is one of the three primary germ layers that form during embryonic development.
  • The ectoderm gives rise to the skin, hair, nails, and the nervous system.
  • The epidermis itself is formed by the surface ectoderm, which begins to thicken and form a layer of cells called the basal layer.
  • On the other hand, the dermis is derived from the mesoderm, which is another one of the primary germ layers.
  • The mesoderm gives rise to a number of different structures in the body, including muscles, bones, and connective tissue.
  • The dermis itself is formed from the mesenchymal cells that migrate into the developing skin from the mesoderm.
  • These cells differentiate into fibroblasts, which then produce the extracellular matrix that forms the dermis.
  • During development, the epidermis and dermis layers interact and become tightly integrated.
  • As the epidermis differentiates, it sends signals to the underlying mesenchymal cells to produce the dermis, and the two layers eventually become fully functional together as the skin.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: This statement is generally accurate. In adults, the skin weighs about 8-10 pounds and has a surface area of about 2 square meters. The skin is the largest organ of the body, and its weight can be roughly estimated to be around 15% of the total body weight, although this can vary based on individuals and their body compositions.

 

Option C. Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is true. The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin and is indeed derived from the ectoderm during embryonic development. It's a stratified squamous epithelium that mainly consists of keratinocytes in progressive stages of differentiation, from the basal layer to the surface. The epidermis provides the body with a barrier against pathogens, UV radiation, and water loss.

 

Option D. Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: This statement is true. The dermis, which provides the skin's strength and elasticity, primarily consists of type 1 collagen, but it also contains a smaller amount of type 3 collagen, especially in the papillary dermis (the uppermost layer of the dermis). These collagens are essential for skin's resilience and durability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dermis is derived from the mesoderm, not the ectoderm.

choices.text: Anterior dislocation of hip
Posterior dislocation of hip
Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
Fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A patient fell down riding a bicycle. He started having pain around hip. There was shortening of limb, and the attitude of limb was Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • Dashboard injury: occur with axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction - seen as one sits in the front seat of the car.
       
  • The typical attitude of the lower limb would be a flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR).

 

 

  • Complications: AVN of femoral head, sciatic nerve injury, associated fractures of femoral head and acetabulum and also associated knee injuries.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • CT scan is the best investigation to judge dislocation.
     
  • Treatment:
    • More the deformity is a sign that probably there is no associated fracture of acetabulum or femoral head/neck. These cases can undergo closed reduction under some sedation.
    • Reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip. It is less common than posterior dislocation. It is of 2 types. Type I: Pubic (femoral head lies superiorly) and Type II: Obturator (femoral head lies inferiorly). Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture (FABER) at the affected hip, with restriction of movement. Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type). Dislocation is usually seen on AP view. Treatment is reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

 

 

Option C. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur. The patients suffering from intertrochanteric femoral fractures are mainly of elder age group (> 60 years of age) with poor health condition & comorbidities. It is seen more commonly in males. The patient presents with severe pain, swelling & ecchymosis. There is tenderness present over the greater trochanter. The hip is externally rotated to > 45° (lateral border of foot touches the couch). There is > 1 inch of shortening in the affected limb. Broadening of greater trochanter is seen. The patient is unable to walk and SLR is also not possible.

 

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. They are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. Non-operative management for these fractures is rarely the treatment course. Young patients with femoral neck fractures will require treatment with emergent open reduction internal fixation. Non-displaced fractures are treated typically with percutaneous cannulated screws or a sliding hip screw. With displaced fractures in less active elderly patients, the treatment is given by hemiarthroplasty and with more active individuals, total hip arthroplasty is done.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The limb position of flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR) is specific of posterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities is not a feature of refeeding syndrome? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperkalemia

 


Refeeding syndrome occurs when a person who has been malnourished starts to eat again. This condition is characterized by metabolic and electrolyte imbalances caused by a sudden shift from a catabolic state (where the body breaks down tissue for energy) to an anabolic state (where the body builds tissue). When refeeding begins, there is an increase in glucose intake, which leads to increased insulin secretion.

 

Hyperkalemia is not a feature of refeeding syndrome. In fact, the opposite occurs (hypokalemia) due to the insulin-mediated intracellular shift of potassium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypophosphatemia: Insulin promotes the uptake of glucose and the subsequent metabolic processes that require phosphate. As phosphate is consumed in the generation of ATP and other metabolic pathways, its levels in the blood decrease, leading to hypophosphatemia.

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: Insulin also drives potassium into cells. As potassium moves intracellularly, the serum potassium levels drop, resulting in hypokalemia.

 

Option D. Hypomagnesemia: Magnesium is a crucial cofactor for many enzymatic reactions, especially those involving ATP. As the metabolic rate increases, magnesium is used up, leading to hypomagnesemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Refeeding syndrome is characterized by hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia, not hyperkalemia.

questions.text: What is the airway management of choice in a patient with maxillofacial trauma after a road traffic accident? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tracheostomy

 

Explanation:

 

Tracheostomy is the preferred airway management technique in cases of severe maxillofacial trauma. This approach is chosen because severe facial injuries can make other forms of intubation difficult or impossible due to anatomical disruptions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Orotracheal Intubation: Typically the first-line method in emergency airway management, it may be contraindicated or challenging in maxillofacial trauma due to the risk of causing further injury.

 

Option C. Nasotracheal Intubation: Avoided in maxillofacial injuries due to the risk of creating a false passage or worsening a basal skull fracture.

 

Option D. Oxygen Therapy: While important for providing oxygen, it does not secure the airway and is insufficient in cases of airway compromise.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In severe maxillofacial trauma where the airway is compromised, an emergency tracheostomy is often necessary if orotracheal intubation is not feasible or safe due to the extent of the injuries.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient has malaise for 2 weeks. His investigations revealed an elevated creatinine of 4.5mg/dl. His blood tests also showed the presence of HBs antigen. A renal biopsy was performed which demonstrated spike and dome on special staining. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous glomerulopathy

 

The elderly patient is having a renal dysfunction. The presence of a ‘spike and dome’ pattern on special staining (silver staining) is suggestive of immune complex deposition. This is characteristic of membranous glomerulopathy. The diagnosis isd also supported by the presence of HBs antigen as the hepatitis B infection is characteristically associated with development of membranous glomerulopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimal change disease: Typically presents with nephrotic syndrome in children and does not show the spike and dome pattern on biopsy. No change on light microscopy; Electron microscopy shows podocyte effacement

 

Option C. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Characterized by segmental scarring of some glomeruli, not associated with the spike and dome pattern.

 

Option D. Renal amyloidosis: Demonstrates amyloid deposits that can be identified with Congo red staining and apple-green birefringence under polarized light, not a spike and dome pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Membranous glomerulopathy, associated with hepatitis B infection, presents with nephrotic syndrome and demonstrates a characteristic spike and dome pattern on renal biopsy due to subepithelial immune complex deposits.

 

Histology: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM)

questions.text: A patient complains of decreased sensation in the lateral 3 ½ fingers of the palmar side of the right hand along with difficulty moving the upper phalanx of the thumb. Associated thenar atrophy is also present. What is the associated nerve injury in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High median nerve

 

The symptoms described in the question indicate involvement of the median nerve, particularly the high median nerve. The high median nerve innervates the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, controls thumb movement, and supplies the thenar muscles responsible for thumb functions. Injury to this nerve can lead to sensory loss and motor deficits, such as difficulty moving the thumb and thenar atrophy, as mentioned in the question. The presence of sensory loss, along with thenar atrophy, strongly indicates a high median nerve injury, rather than its branches like the anterior interosseous nerve, which does not affect sensory perception.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily supplies the medial side of the hand, including the little finger and half of the ring finger. It does not innervate the lateral 3 ½ fingers or the thenar muscles. Therefore, an injury to the ulnar nerve would not present with the described sensory and motor deficits.

 

Option B. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and provides sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand. It does not supply the thenar muscles or the palmar side of the fingers described in the question. Hence, it cannot be the correct answer.

 

Option C. Anterior interosseous nerve: This nerve is a deep branch of the median nerve, which primarily supplies deep muscles in the forearm like the flexor pollicis longus, pronator quadratus, and part of the flexor digitorum profundus. It does not carry sensory fibers, so it would not cause sensory loss or thenar atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high median nerve injury is characterized by sensory loss in the lateral 3 ½ fingers on the palmar side, difficulty moving the thumb, and associated thenar atrophy.

questions.text: Plaques Jaunes are seen in: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Head injury

 

Explanation: 

 

Plaques jaunes (meaning "yellow plaques" in French) are yellowish-brown, depressed, retracted patches involving the crests of gyri that represent the end-stage appearance of traumatic brain contusions. These lesions develop as a result of the long-term healing process following traumatic brain injury. Old traumatic lesions characteristically develop these yellow-brown discolored areas on the brain surface, particularly at sites where the brain has impacted against the skull. Histologically, these areas show gliosis and residual hemosiderin-laden macrophages, representing the final stage of resolution of a traumatic contusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syphilis - Neurosyphilis can produce several patterns of CNS involvement including meningovascular neurosyphilis, paretic neurosyphilis, and tabes dorsalis, but plaques jaunes are not characteristic of syphilitic infection. Neurosyphilis typically shows meningeal inflammation, obliterative endarteritis, and in some cases, parenchymal damage.

 

Option C. Endocarditis - Infective endocarditis can lead to cerebral complications through septic emboli, resulting in multiple infarcts or abscesses, but these do not produce the characteristic yellow plaques seen in healed traumatic lesions.

 

Option D. Atherosclerosis - Cerebral atherosclerosis can lead to ischemic infarcts that eventually form cavitations, but these typically appear as fluid-filled cavities with surrounding gliosis rather than the yellow surface discoloration characteristic of plaques jaunes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Plaques jaunes are pathognomonic for healed traumatic brain contusions, appearing as yellowish-brown, depressed scars on the crests of gyri at sites of previous trauma, representing the end-stage of traumatic brain injury healing.

questions.text: A farmer had a thorn prick 3 weeks ago and presents with difficulty in opening jaw and muscle cramps. He is also having breathlessness. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus

 

The patient presents with classic symptoms of tetanus, which include difficulty in opening the jaw (trismus), muscle cramps, and breathlessness. Tetanus is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani, which is often introduced through a wound such as a thorn prick. The symptoms of tetanus can develop days to weeks after the initial injury, as is the case here with the 3-week history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine poisoning can cause severe muscle spasms and cramps, but it typically presents acutely and is associated with a history of ingestion of the poison rather than an injury. Additionally, strychnine poisoning does not usually present with trismus (lockjaw).

 

Option C. Meningitis: Meningitis can cause symptoms like headache, fever, and neck stiffness, but it does not typically cause muscle cramps and difficulty in opening the jaw in the manner described.

 

Option D. Rabies: Rabies can cause neurological symptoms including hydrophobia and agitation, but it does not usually present with muscle cramps and trismus as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of tetanus should be considered in a patient with a history of a wound or injury followed by symptoms such as trismus, muscle cramps, and breathlessness, particularly if the onset of symptoms is delayed.

questions.text: Identify the condition based on this image: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kartagener syndrome

 

The image shows a chest X-ray with dextrocardia, a condition where the heart is positioned on the right side of the chest. This is a key feature of situs inversus, which is commonly associated with Kartagener syndrome.

 

Kartagener syndrome is characterized by a triad of clinical features: recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The presence of situs inversus, as indicated by dextrocardia on the X-ray, is a distinguishing feature that confirms the diagnosis of Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system, characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can clog the airways and lead to infections. It does not typically present with situs inversus or dextrocardia.

 

Option C. Young syndrome: Young syndrome also involves recurrent sinusitis and bronchiectasis, similar to Kartagener syndrome. However, it is distinguished by infertility due to azoospermia rather than situs inversus. The absence of dextrocardia or situs inversus on imaging excludes Young syndrome as the correct answer.

 

Option D. Atrophic rhinitis: Atrophic rhinitis is characterized by chronic nasal inflammation leading to crusting, foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal block, and enlarged nasal cavities. It does not involve bronchiectasis, recurrent sinusitis, or situs inversus, making it unrelated to the features seen in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:


Kartagener syndrome is identified by the presence of recurrent sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus (including dextrocardia), which is clearly visible in the chest X-ray provided.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

 

Explanation

 

  • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter:
    • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
    • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.

 

Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.

 

Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Police brought a person from the railway track with features of dry mouth, dilated pupil, dry skin, slurring of speech, and delirium. What could be the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dhatura


Dhatura poisoning is associated with anticholinergic toxidrome, which presents with features such as dry mouth, dilated pupils, dry skin, slurred speech, and delirium. Anticholinergic substances like Dhatura inhibit the action of acetylcholine, leading to reduced secretions, dilated pupils, and central nervous system effects like confusion and delirium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid and falls under the category of CNS depressants. Opioids typically cause pupil constriction (miosis), not dilation, and do not produce dry skin or dry mouth, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol, especially in the early stages, may cause pupil dilation but usually presents with wet skin and slurred speech due to CNS depression, not dry features. Dry skin and mouth are not characteristic of alcohol intoxication, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Cocaine: Cocaine is a sympathomimetic agent, which can cause pupil dilation but does not cause dry mouth or dry skin. Cocaine typically increases body secretions rather than reducing them, so this does not fit the anticholinergic profile described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:


Dhatura poisoning exhibits an anticholinergic toxidrome characterized by dry mouth, dry skin, dilated pupils, and altered mental status, distinguishing it from other toxidromes.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pterygium

 

The likely diagnosis, based on the above image, is pterygium.

  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.
  • It is a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea from either side within the interpalpebral fissure.
  • It is more common in people living in hot climates, and a response to prolonged effect of environmental factors such as exposure to sun (ultraviolet rays), dry heat, high wind and abundance of dust.

 

Clinical features:

  • It is more common in elderly males doing outdoor work.
  • It may be unilateral or bilateral.
  • It presents as a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching the cornea in the area of palpebral aperture, usually on the nasal side but may also occur on the temporal side.
  • Deposition of iron seen sometimes in corneal epithelium anterior to advancing head of pterygium is called stocker's line.
  • Mostly asymptomatic.
  • Irritation and grittiness are caused by a dellen – localized drying of tear film.
  • Cosmesis may be a significant problem.
  • Visual disturbances occur when it encroaches the pupillary area or due to corneal astigmatism induced due to fibrosis in the regressive stage.
  • Diplopia may occur due to limitation of ocular movements.
  • PARTS OF A PTERYGIUM:

 

A fully developed pterygium consists of three parts

  1. Head (apical part present on the cornea),
  2. Neck (limbal part), and
  3. Body (scleral part) extending between limbus and the canthus.

 

Differences between pterygium and pseudopterygium

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pinguecula: A yellowish, benign growth on the conjunctiva that does not encroach onto the cornea.

 

Option B. Concretions: Small, yellowish-white deposits on the conjunctiva, often associated with chronic conjunctivitis.

 

Option D. Bitot's spots: Foamy, whitish lesions on the conjunctiva, typically associated with vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pterygium is characterized by a wing-shaped fold of conjunctiva encroaching upon the cornea, commonly seen in people exposed to prolonged environmental factors like UV rays and dust. The treatment includes surgical removal and techniques to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: What is the proper disposal method for a damaged vaccine vial according to biomedical waste management protocols? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Puncture proof blue bin 

 

Blue puncture proof container

 

Under BMW guidelines, Glassware and Metallic Body Implants are disposed in Cardboard boxes with blue colored marking/ puncture proof bins. These bins are specifically designed to safely handle glass and metallic body implants to prevent injury and ensure proper disposal.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Wide local excision with skin grafting

questions.text: A 4-week-old baby presented with an erythematous lesion which was blanching and increasing in size as shown in the image below. What is the next best step in the management of this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Observe

 

Presentation & Diagnosis

 

  • Neonate presenting with an erythematous, blanching lesion on the abdomen. 
  • Characteristic features point to an infantile hemangioma, a benign vascular tumor common in neonates.

 

Natural History 

 

Proliferative Phase: 

 

  • Rapid growth typically observed until about 9 months of age. 

 

Involution Phase: 

 

  • A slow regression phase follows, extending over several years until spontaneous resolution.

 

Location & Complication Assessment 

 

Location: 

 

  • The lesion is on the abdomen, a non-vital area (not affecting vision, breathing, or feeding). 

 

Complications: 

 

  • No signs of ulceration, bleeding, or interference with vital functions.

 

Management Strategy 

 

Observation: 

 

  • Given the predictable natural history and absence of complications, the best approach is conservative management through observation.    

 

Parental Reassurance: 

 

  • It is essential to inform and reassure parents about the benign nature and expected spontaneous regression of the lesion.

 

Regular Monitoring: 

 

  • Continuous follow-up is necessary to ensure proper regression and to monitor for any potential complications.

 

Indications for Intervention

 

Active treatment is reserved for cases where the hemangioma: 

 

  • Compromises vital structures (e.g., near the eyes, nose, or airway). 

 

 

  • Is associated with complications such as ulceration or bleeding. 
  • Is large and disfiguring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser

 

  • Not first-line treatment for uncomplicated infantile hemangiomas
  • Unnecessarily aggressive for a self-resolving condition
  • May cause scarring in a condition that naturally resolves
  • Reserved for residual telangiectasias after involution

 

Option B. Wide local excision with skin grafting

 

  • Too aggressive for a benign, self-limiting condition
  • Surgery indicated only for specific cases like ulcerated lesions
  • Unnecessary scarring and surgical risk
  • Not justified when natural resolution is expected

 

Option D. Injection triamcinolone

 

  • Not indicated for uncomplicated infantile hemangiomas
  • Local complications like atrophy can occur
  • Systemic beta-blockers like propranolol have largely replaced steroids as the treatment of choice for complicated hemangiomas. 
  • No indication for intralesional steroids in this case

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Infantile hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that undergo spontaneous involution. 
  • Observation is the best initial management for uncomplicated cases. 
  • Propranolol is the first-line treatment for high-risk or complicated hemangiomas.

choices.text: It is negative in most children in the first 6 months of life
It is an important aid in classifying the type of leprosy disease
BCG vaccination may convert a lepra reaction from negative to positive

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lepromin test is not true? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) It is a diagnostic test

 

  • The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test for leprosy. Instead, it is used to assess the immune response (cell-mediated immunity) in individuals exposed to Mycobacterium leprae, the bacteria that cause leprosy.
  • This test helps in classifying the type of leprosy and predicting the prognosis. It involves injecting a standardized antigen into the skin and observing the reaction, which is measured at specific intervals. While the test is useful in understanding the immune status and classifying the disease, it is not suitable for diagnosing leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is negative in most children in the first 6 months of life: Incorrect because it is true that the lepromin test is usually negative in young children under 6 months, as their immune system may not yet produce a significant reaction.

 

Option C. It is an important aid in classifying the type of leprosy disease: Incorrect because it is true that the lepromin test helps in classifying leprosy, distinguishing between tuberculoid and lepromatous forms based on the immune response.

 

Option D. BCG vaccination may convert a lepra reaction from negative to positive: Incorrect as BCG vaccination can indeed convert a previously negative lepromin test to positive, indicating a boosted immune response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The lepromin test is not used for diagnosing leprosy but is valuable for assessing immune response and classifying the type of leprosy.

choices.text: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6
The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10
These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease
No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Gamma-Release-Assays for the diagnosis of Tuberculosis is correct? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. The Second Generation QuantiFERON-TB (Gold) assay uses both ESAT-6 and CFP-10

 

Explanation:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold (second generation) assay utilizes two specific antigens - ESAT-6 (Early Secretory Antigenic Target-6) and CFP-10 (Culture Filtrate Protein-10) for detecting TB infection. These antigens are present in M. tuberculosis complex but absent in BCG vaccine strains and most non-tuberculous mycobacteria, making them more specific for TB detection compared to tuberculin skin tests.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: The First Generation QuantiFERON-TB assay utilized ESAT-6 This is incorrect because the first generation QuantiFERON-TB assay used tuberculin PPD (purified protein derivative) as the stimulating antigen, not ESAT-6. This made it less specific than the second generation test.

 

Option C: These tests can differentiate between Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection and active disease This is incorrect as IGRAs (Interferon-Gamma Release Assays) including QuantiFERON cannot differentiate between latent TB infection and active TB disease. They only detect immune response to TB antigens, indicating exposure or infection.

 

Option D: No non-tuberculous mycobacteria produce a positive reaction in this assay This is incorrect because some non-tuberculous mycobacteria (such as M. kansasii, M. marinum, and M. szulgai) also possess genes for ESAT-6 and CFP-10, potentially causing false-positive results in the assay.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The QuantiFERON-TB Gold assay uses ESAT-6 and CFP-10 antigens to improve specificity over the first generation test, but still cannot distinguish between latent infection and active disease.
